faqs.question: What's included in electrical safety certification?
faqs.answer: We inspect: electrical panel (brand, capacity, condition), wiring type and visible condition, outlet testing (grounding, polarity), GFCI function, visible wiring conditions, and general electrical system assessment. Documentation covers all inspected items.

faqs.question: Is this the same as a 4-point inspection?
faqs.answer: We provide the electrical portion of 4-point inspections. The full 4-point covers roof, HVAC, plumbing, and electrical. Some clients need only electrical; others need us as part of complete 4-point coordination.

faqs.question: What if you find problems during inspection?
faqs.answer: We document problems objectively. You decide next steps: repair before certification, disclose issues as-is, or understand the situation for planning. We can quote and perform repairs if you choose to address issues.

faqs.question: How long does certification take?
faqs.answer: Inspection typically takes 1-2 hours depending on property size. Written certification is usually available within 24-48 hours. Expedited service is available for urgent needs.

faqs.question: Will you pass me if my panel is old?
faqs.answer: Age alone doesn't fail inspection. Condition, capacity, and safety matter. Old-but-functional panels can pass. Recalled brands (Federal Pacific, Zinsco) are always noted as concerns. We document accurately what we find.

faqs.question: What format is the certification?
faqs.answer: We provide professional certification letters and/or detailed inspection reports. Format can be adapted to specific requirements—insurance forms, real estate formats, or standard certification letters.

faqs.question: Can certification be updated after repairs?
faqs.answer: Yes. If initial inspection identifies issues and you complete repairs, we can re-inspect and provide updated certification reflecting the corrected condition.

faqs.question: Is certification valid indefinitely?
faqs.answer: Certification documents conditions at time of inspection. Most insurers and buyers accept certifications within the last 6-12 months. Commercial requirements may specify validity periods. We date all certifications clearly.
